newsitem.title: USA: U.S. shuttle launch further delayed.
newsitem.headline: U.S. shuttle launch further delayed.

text.p: Faced with a dismal weather forecast, NASA called off its plans to launch shuttle Columbia this weekend and rescheduled the start of its 16-day mission for Tuesday, space agency officials said on Wednesday.
Meteorologists had painted a bleak picture of strong gusty winds, cloudy skies and rain for planned Saturday and Sunday launch attempts, but forecast better conditions by Tuesday.
NASA managers decided at a meeting held late Wednesday afternoon to put the countdown on hold until the weather improved.
"They had a solid no-go forecast through to Sunday," said NASA spokesman Rob Navias. "In requesting Tuesday we have given ourselves an opportunity to let this weather clear."
Blastoff from Florida's Kennedy Space Centre was retargeted for 2:53 p.m. EST (1953 GMT) on Tuesday.
Earlier Wednesday, NASA had delayed the mission by one day so an unmanned rocket, grounded by high winds, could make a second launch attempt on Thursday (tomorrow).
Columbia was already running a week late due to booster rocket problems.
The shuttle's crew of five will wait out the delay at the Florida launch site, Navias said.

The astronauts are due to spend 16 days in orbit conducting scientific research with a pair of free-flying satellites. Two spacewalks are also planned to practice for the construction of the international space station.
